title: 114_hr4783
content: The Act titled "Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016" extends termination dates for SBIR and STTR programs from 2017 to 2022. Administrative funding deadlines are also extended to 2022. Required expenditure amounts are specified. The Small Business Act is amended to specify required expenditure amounts for SBIR funding in fiscal years 2018 to 2022 and beyond. The Small Business Act is amended to specify required expenditure amounts for STTR funding in fiscal years 2018 to 2022 and beyond, with percentages increasing annually. SEC. 4. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. Annual reporting requirements under the Small Business Act have been amended to specify deadlines for submitting reports to Congress and the Administrator, with the deadline for submission set for December 31 and March 30 of each year, respectively. The Small Business Act has been amended to require agencies to submit a simplified and standardized report to the Administration by March 30 of each year. Additionally, agencies must report all instances to the Administration by the same deadline. The Small Business Act amendments mandate agencies to submit reports by specific deadlines each year, such as March 30 and June 30, for various subsections. The Small Business Act amendments require Federal agencies to report on the use of administrative funds by March 30 each year. Failure to submit the report will result in certain provisions not applying. Federal agencies must submit a report on the use of administrative funds by March 30 each year to ensure timely reporting. Failure to submit the report will result in certain provisions not applying. SEC. 5. INDEXING AWARDS FOR INFLATION. Section 9 of the Small Business Act (15 U.S.C. 638) is amended to make various changes to subsections (j)(2), (p)(2)(B), and (gg)(3), including redesignating subparagraphs, adding and striking clauses, and updating references to awards. The Small Business Act is amended to set limits on awards for Phase I and Phase II of SBIR or STTR programs, with Phase I awards capped at $150,000 and Phase II awards capped at $1,000,000, adjusted for inflation. SEC. 6 amends the Small Business Act to change wording regarding insertion incentives. SEC. 7 clarifies eligibility for certain small businesses. The Small Business Act is amended to clarify eligibility for certain small businesses under the SBIR and STTR programs. The Administrator is required to modify policy directives within 180 days to ensure that specific small business concerns are eligible for awards. The Small Business Act is amended to clarify eligibility for certain small businesses under the SBIR and STTR programs, with the Administrator required to modify policy directives within 180 days to ensure specific small business concerns are eligible for awards. SEC. 8. COMMERCIALIZATION ASSISTANCE PILOT PROGRAM. Section 9 of the Small Business Act is amended to include a Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program, requiring covered agencies to implement a program to award eligible entities with a second sequential SBIR award within one year of the enactment of the Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016. The Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program requires covered agencies to award eligible entities with a second sequential SBIR award within one year of the enactment of the Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016. The program limits agency funds to 5% of the total SBIR budget and terminates on September 30, 2022. Recipients must provide a matching amount equal to the award received. The Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program requires eligible entities to provide a matching amount from a third-party investor before the end of the award period. Awards under the program are limited in size and distributed during the Phase II award period. To be selected for a second sequential SBIR award under a commercialization assistance pilot program, an eligible entity must submit an application with required information and matching funding details. The funds awarded can only be used for research and development activities that advance towards commercialization. Recipients are determined based on their applications. When awarding funds under the commercialization assistance pilot program, the agency head considers the potential for research commercialization, technical feasibility, improvements to the commercialization plan, and the progress of the small business concern in Phase II activities. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit an evaluation report on the commercialization assistance pilot programs, including a summary of activities and results achieved, to relevant committees within 3 years of the enactment of the Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016. The evaluation report on commercialization assistance pilot programs will include results achieved, commercialization rates, growth in employment and revenue, comparison of success with non-matching Phase II recipients, demographic information of participant companies, and funds used at each agency. The evaluation report on commercialization assistance pilot programs will include details on participating agencies, distribution of third-party funding, program effectiveness analysis, and recommendations for improvement. Definitions for covered agency and eligible entity are also provided.
